subject: Re: Aesthetic Concerns for a new font.
msgSnippet: ... speed ... As you will see from my layout above, I have attempted to take on this task in an elegant manner that will also allow for the non-use of half
messageBody:
> Now on to a larger issue: It appears to me that the issue of
> "half-letters" needs addressing directly at the start of your
> project. Their adoption in handwriting is designed to increase
speed
> in writing and, I suspect, just because they are pretty and add to
> the visual flow of the script.

As you will see from my layout above, I have attempted to take on this
task in an elegant manner that will also allow for the non-use of half
letters if so desired (you will note that they are all assigned shift
keys).

> On the other hand, if beauty and display are the main goals of
> writing QS on a computer, then the number of keystrokes be damned.
> Hail to the half-letters, and any other myriad linkages that may be
> thought of!

I hope that you will find that my proposed layout minimizes the work
to find and use the half-letters by assigning them all as shift-keys
to their full counterparts.

> (If goal 2 is the one you choose, a suggestion here: the Jerome
> font seems to have been designed in a Luddite manner, as if for a
> 1900 Smith Corona, utilizing only the good old shift key for odd
> characters. If one acknowledges that we are indeed designing for a
> computer keyboard, then we have the Command (or Apple), Option, and
> Control Keys at our disposal, all within a quarter inch of the old
> Shift key.. Thus every basic character could have 4 variations,
> instead of 1, and still reside on a logical home key.)

Unneccessary and complicated to learn. Once again, I feel my layout
addresses this in an elegant method (I hope). It is still protean if
it needs to be, so that's why I've posted it here; for suggestions.

> Another question that arises: should the sounds be assigned to the
> QWERTY arrangement of letters (another Luddite scheme if there ever
> was on, but advantageous for those that look at the keyboard) or
> should they be assigned according to phoneme frequency of use,
> requiring minimal finger movement, a la Dvorak? Could we have a
> referendum on that please? (I do have some pseudo-scientific
> information on phoneme frequency.)

Just because it's Luddite doesn't mean we can do away with it as
quickly as we would like. As I have written in the documentation for
this font:

==============================================

===1. Mission Goals===


-i. Why another font?

There are already at least a couple of fonts available for the Read
Alphabet, the most popular of which is called Jerrome.ttf. It is a
very good font, but I thought it could be taken a few steps further
and, rather than attempt to "hack" the font to suit my needs, I
decided to create a new one from scratch for reasons of consistancy
and my personal preference to use all GPL'ed or free tools.

-ii. Why use this font?

IMHO, this font is superior to others for the following reasons:

1) A more intuitive keyboard layout.

While Readscrip tis intended to be an alphabet REPLACEMENT, we
ourselves do not have the benefit of being raised in a society where
Readscript is the native alphabet. Further, while T.O. may be
inefficient, it is yet bound (at least in our minds) to Readscript
out of this relationship of replacement. It is clear then, if
the Readscript Revolution :) is to come to pass, that a transitory
step is needed for a transitory generation. We cannot very well
expect to throw out billions of keyboards overnight, nor can we
expect to ever grasp Readscript as intuitively as the generations
following the (hopeful) alphabet reform.

I have tried my best to provide an intuitive keyboard layout based
on a one-to-one conversion between the sounds of T.O. and those
represented by the Read Alphabet. This, I hope, will provide a
more efficient mnemonic foundation than other Readscript fonts, and
will hopefully lead to faster typing due to the ease of association.

Further, it is hoped that this layout may even correspondingly serve
to more firmly embed the Readscript symbols in the memory of the
typist, leading towards faster writing/reading skill on paper as
well.

Of course, if this layout is as much easier and widely accepted as
I hope it will be, this may even lead to a larger base of reading
material written in or converted to Readscript. The benefits of
this type of "knowledge base" should be obvious. :)
==============================================

> And finallly, one request: in your work don't forget us Mac users
> when you do publish your font.

Of course not. It will work on Macintosh or I'll die trying to make
it work on Macintosh. I am a Free Software ADVOCATE, not a bigot. I
like Mac OS. :)

-A
